co2_title:
CO₂ emissions (use phase)

The CO₂ values refer to the current electricity mix in Germany.
desc1: Select which year the vehicle was purchased.
desc10: A German law proposes to change accounting rules for electrical vehicles.
desc11: For details see the online calculator documentation (available only in German).
desc15:
Traffic conditions (e.g. proportion of stop and go) can influence maintenance and repair costs.
Compared to the option 'normal traffic', maintenance and repair costs are increased by 20% (heavy traffic) or 100% (very heavy traffic).
desc17: Battery charging infrastructure costs are divided by the chosen fleet size.
desc18: How the persons in charge of vehicle maintenance are trained to work with electrical vehicles.
desc19: Total cost of the training for all electrical vehicles of the fleet
desc2: Number of years the car is used by the owner
desc20: For plug-in hybrid vehicles, this value represents the electric energy consumption in full electric mode.
desc21: Plug-in hybrid vehicles can run in different modes  (e.g. full electric, full inner combustion engine, combined mode). To simplify, the online TCO calculator considers the full electric mode and the pure combustion mode only.
desc22: Selecting this option doubles the maximum full electric range for the trend figures.
desc23:
The chosen full electric range is used in battery size and vehicle cost calculations.
For plug-in hybrid vehicles the full electric range is used to calculate a maximum share of full-electric driven annual driving ranges in figure 'See the evolution'.
For details see the online calculator documention (only available in German).
desc24: For details see the online calculator documentation (available only in German).
desc25: Number of years the second user of the vehicle keeps it
desc26: Number of kilometers driven per year by the second user
desc27: Maximal number of battery charges before a battery change is needed
desc28: Option relevant for calculating greenhouse gas emissions. For details see the online calculator documentation (available only in German).
desc3: Average distance driven in a year (in km)
desc32: For details see the online calculator documentation (available only in German).
desc33: In Germany until 2019, electric and plug-in hybrid vehicle customers can take advantage of a direct subsidy of 4,000€ (electric vehicles) or 3,000 € (plug-in hybrid vehicles), if the price of the vehicle (standard configuration) is below 60,000€ and if the manufacturer participates.
desc35: Average inflation rate in Germany (2004 - 2015) was 1.5%. Source: Statistisches Bundesamt
desc36: The price of gasoline is based on germany's average 2015 fuel price and the applied fuel price developments.
desc37: The price of diesel is based on germany's average 2015 fuel price and the applied fuel price developments.
desc38: The calculation is based on Germany's average household electricity price in 2015 and the applied electricity price developments from 2016-2020.
desc39: For details see the online calculator documentation (available only in German).
desc4: For passenger cars (small, medium and large), diesel, gasoline, plug-in hybrid and electric vehicles can be chosen. For light duty vehicles, diesel and electric vehicles can be chosen.
desc40: For details see the online calculator documentation (available only in German).
desc41: For details see the online calculator documentation (available only in German).
desc42: For details see the online calculator documentation (available only in German).
desc5:
Passenger car – small (A: mini, B: small; e.g. smart for two, VW Polo)
Passenger car – medium (C: medium, M: multi-purpose; e.g. VW Golf, Mercedes A-Class)
Passenger car – large (D: large, F: luxury, J: sport utility; e.g. Audi A5, Mercedes S-Class, VW Tiguan)
Light duty vehicle – small (e.g. VW Caddy, Mercedes Vito)
Light duty vehicle – large (e.g. VW Crafter, Mercedes Sprinter)
desc6: Option to choose the type of battery charging infrastructure.
desc7: For plug-in-hybrid vehicles, this value represents the fuel consumption in a full combustion engine mode.
desc8: The tax rate for corporate gains
evolution electricity 2010-2020: Evolution of the price of electricity (2010-2020)
evolution electricity 2020-2030: Evolution of the price of electricity (2020-2030)
evolution electricity 2030-2050: Evolution of the price of electricity (2030-2050)
evolution petrol price: Evolution of the price of a barrel of oil
expl1:
This diagram shows the total cost of vehicle depending on the the time the company holds it for. The bands on each side of the line represent variations of the scenario assumptions for fuel prices, electricity prices and battery prices (in each case ± 10%).
* Discounted to the year of acquisition.
expl2:
This diagram shows the total costs of the vehicles depending on the annual mileage driven. The bands on each side of the line represent variations of the scenario assumptions for fuel prices, electricity prices and battery prices (in each case ± 10%)..
* Discounted to the year of acquisition.
expl3: This diagram shows the total vehicle cost depending on how long the company owns it. Greenhouse gas emissions are measured according to their climate impact and shown as CO₂ equivalents.
expl4: The diagram shows the greenhouse gas emissions during the vehicle's use phase as a function of the annual driving performance. The displayed CO₂ values refer to the current electricity mix in Germany. If self-generated renewable electricity is used, the electric vehicle is practically driven without CO₂ emissions. However, it is estimated that the production of a medium-sized electric vehicle causes an additional 4-5 tonnes of CO₂ equivalents compared to the production of a comparable vehicle with combustion engine. Greenhouse gas emissions are rated according to their climate impact and presented as CO₂ equivalents.
expl5:
This graph shows the breakdown of the cost positions for a vehicle.
* Discounted to the year of acquisition.
** Acquisition costs - residual value - subsidy
expl6:
This diagram shows the total vehicle cost depending on the acquisition year. The bands on each side of the line represent variations of the scenario assumptions for fuel prices, electricity prices and battery prices (in each case ± 10%).
* Discounted to the year of acquisition.
expl7: This diagram shows the greenhouse gas emissions depending on the year the vehicle is acquired. Greenhouse gas emissions are measured according to their climate impact and shown as CO₂ equivalents.

Number of electrical vehicles in fleet: Number of electrical vehicles in fleet
start_btn_gewerb: Online calculator for electric vehicles (commercial use)
start_btn_privat: Online calculator for electric vehicles (private use)
welcome_description_1: Out of more than 3 million new car registrations per year in Germany about 800,000 cars are attributed to corporate vehicle fleets – representing a huge potential for electromobility. Using electric vehicles in a corporate vehicle fleet offers several advantages compared to private use. Firstly, the restricted driving range is less problematic when there is the possibility to switch to other vehicles in the fleet. Furthermore, the charging facilities installed on the company premises can be used by several cars, which contributes to cost reduction. When the use of the vehicles is well planned and use conflicts are avoided, vehicle utilization and cost-effectiveness can be improved.
welcome_description_2: About 40% of all new electric cars are private vehicles. Although private users on average drive less kilometers per year and have less tax advantages compared to commercial users, they are increasingly ready to buy the new technology. Most private car owners also have the possibility to install a charging point at home which makes it easy to recharge the electric car overnight.
welcome_description_3:
What are the total costs of an electric vehicle compared to a diesel or gasoline vehicle?

How could the total costs develop in the coming years?

Which impact do important cost factors like holding period and annual mileage have on the total costs?

How many greenhouse gas emissions can be saved by switching to electric vehicles?

Find it out! By using the online calculator you can analyze the costs and CO2 emissions associated with car driving. The approach of total cost analysis (TCO – Total Cost of Ownership) includes all cost factors, namely vehicle acquisition, charging infrastructure, costs for fuel and electric energy, vehicle maintenance, taxes, insurance and the residual value of the vehicles. For a start you can use plausible default values and for a more personal analysis you can modify many input variables according to your preferences.
